articles.headline: Payday Lending Faces Tough New Restrictions by Consumer Agency
articles.snippet: New rules announced Thursday by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau could largely eliminate short-term, high-interest loans to working-class Americans.
articles.abstract: New rules announced Thursday by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau could largely eliminate short-term, high-interest loans to working-class Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal agency on Thursday imposed tough new restrictions on so-called payday lending, dealing a potentially crushing blow to an industry that churns out billions of dollars a year in high-interest loans to working-class and poor Americans.

articles.headline: Harvey Weinstein Paid Off Sexual Harassment Accusers for Decades
articles.snippet: An investigation by The New York Times found allegations stretching back to 1990 about Mr. Weinstein’s treatment of women in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: An investigation by The New York Times found allegations stretching back to 1990 about Mr. Weinstein’s treatment of women in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein invited Ashley Judd to the Peninsula Beverly Hills hotel for what the young actress expected to be a business breakfast meeting. Instead, he had her sent up to his room, where he appeared in a bathrobe and asked if he could give her a massage or she could watch him shower, she recalled in an interview.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey

articles.headline: Deadly Ambush of Green Berets in Niger Belies a ‘Low-Risk’ Mission
articles.snippet: The deaths of three Special Forces troops raised questions about how they assess threats, as well as about their oversight, Pentagon officials said.
articles.abstract: The deaths of three Special Forces troops raised questions about how they assess threats, as well as about their oversight, Pentagon officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The reconnaissance patrol was supposed to be a routine training mission along the border between Niger and Mali for the nearly dozen United States Army Special Forces trainers and the Nigerien soldiers with them.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Trump to Force Congress to Act on Iran Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: President Trump has been expected to withdraw certification of the nuclear deal since he declared at the United Nations General Assembly that the agreement was “embarrassing to the United States.”
articles.abstract: President Trump has been expected to withdraw certification of the nuclear deal since he declared at the United Nations General Assembly that the agreement was “embarrassing to the United States.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is expected to overrule his top national security advisers and decline to certify the Iran nuclear agreement, according to people who have been briefed on the matter, a decision that would reopen a volatile political debate on Iran but is likely to leave in place the landmark deal negotiated by the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: For Republican Leaders in Congress, the Headaches Keep Mounting
articles.snippet: Republican leaders find themselves under attack from the right and left, questioned by their donors and even threatened by the Trump White House.
articles.abstract: Republican leaders find themselves under attack from the right and left, questioned by their donors and even threatened by the Trump White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders in Congress are under attack from all sides of their own party, battered by voters from the right and left, spurned by frustrated donors and even threatened by the Trump White House for ineffective leadership and insufficient loyalty.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: No Manifesto, No Phone Calls: Las Vegas Killer Left Only Cryptic Clues
articles.snippet: Some mass murderers proclaim what led them to kill. But the clues left behind by Steven Paddock have led only to more questions.
articles.abstract: Some mass murderers proclaim what led them to kill. But the clues left behind by Steven Paddock have led only to more questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read the latest on the Las Vegas shooting with Friday’s live updates.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina, Alexander Burns and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: U.S. Lost 33,000 Jobs in September; Unemployment Rate Dips to 4.2%
articles.snippet: Hurricanes appeared to knock down payroll totals, yielding the first monthly decline in employment in seven years, though economists expect a rebound.
articles.abstract: Hurricanes appeared to knock down payroll totals, yielding the first monthly decline in employment in seven years, though economists expect a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staggering from the impact of hurricanes that walloped Texas, Florida and neighboring states, the economy lost 33,000 jobs in September, the first monthly decline in employment in seven years, the government reported on Friday.

articles.headline: ‘Dear Equifax: You’re Fired.’ If Only It Were That Easy.
articles.snippet: Many readers — and numerous politicians — want Equifax to delete their credit files upon request and not collect any new data. Is that remotely possible?
articles.abstract: Many readers — and numerous politicians — want Equifax to delete their credit files upon request and not collect any new data. Is that remotely possible?
articles.lead_paragraph: The emails have landed in my inbox, one every other day or so since Equifax revealed that cyberthieves had helped themselves to the Social Security numbers and dates of birth of more than 140 million Americans in the company’s files.

articles.headline: Don’t Get Too Comfortable at That Desk
articles.snippet: New designs are partly a backlash to wide-open floor plans and include a “palette of places,” meaning that people don’t sit in just one spot.
articles.abstract: New designs are partly a backlash to wide-open floor plans and include a “palette of places,” meaning that people don’t sit in just one spot.
articles.lead_paragraph: First there were individual offices. Then cubicles and open floor plans. Now, there is a “palette of places.”
